Hazards of Cannulating Fistulas
Purpose

An arteriovenous fistula is an abnormal connection or passageway between an artery and a vein. It may be congenital, surgically created for haemodialysis treatments, or acquired due to pathologic process, such as trauma or erosion of an arterial aneurysm.

The aim of this guideline is to maximise the efficiency and safety of a renal patient's arteriovenous fistula (AVF/ Arteriovenous graft (AVG). This guideline is in line with international best practice guidelines on the management of arteriovenous fistula and grafts.
To support staff in the ongoing management and cannulation of AVF/AVG.
To reduce the potential for adverse incidents and infiltration.
Aim of the Service
Uncomplicated insertion of haemodialysis fistula needle or cannula with minimal trauma and pain for the patient.
Adequate blood flow to achieve optimal dialysis.
The nurse competently solves problems associated with cannulation.
Maximum preservation of access veins for dialysis
To decrease the incidence of hospitalisation and complications such as haematomas or infection from needle trauma.
Safe removal of needles and prevention of life threatening bleeding following haemodialysis treatment.
Introduction

A functioning arteriovenous fistula (AVF) or arteriovenous graft (AVG) is paramount in the maintenance of regular and optimal haemodialysis treatment Haemodialysis nurses are ideally placed to monitor and maintain vascular access patency with regular physical assessment and by implementing correct cannulation techniques. Prompt referral to the Vascular Access Nurse (VAN) and to radiological or surgical intervention is required to preserve the “life line” of the patient.

Fistulas are not to be cannulated within six weeks of creation to allow vessel maturation (K/DOQI, 2006). Although K/DOQI (2006) guidelines suggest AVG can be cannulated after 2 weeks of placement, the vascular surgeons at MEHT Hospital recommend graft cannulation as long as swelling has settled to enable easy identification of graft. The vascular access nurse of haemodialysis charge nurse will liaise with the vascular surgeon regarding
optimal cannulation timing for each access. MEHT renal unit recommends rope ladder cannulation technique with sharp needles for all patients requiring haemodialysis.
Scope of the Service

This guideline applies to the members of the multi-disciplinary team working within the Nephrology Directorate who are involved in the care of adult renal patients undergoing acute or chronic haemodialysis via arteriovenous fistula. All clinical staff trained nurses and untrained staff involved in the ongoing management of AVF/AVG must adhere to the principles described in this guideline.
This does not apply to children
Responsibilities
Renal consultants
5.1.1 Renal consultants must be aware of and familiarise themselves with the guidance issues by British Renal association in relation to vascular access cannulation.
5.1.2 Medical staff are responsible to assess AVF for Haemodialysis patient during their routine renal clinic; they are not responsible to cannulate fistulae.
Lead Nurse/unit manager

5.2.1  The lead nurse for renal and the unit manager is responsible for monitoring the effectiveness of this policy. This will be carried out as an ongoing process and the policy will be subject to a three year review or earlier if required.
Haemodialysis Nurses
5.3.1 Vascular access link nurses (band 6 RN) and the renal team are responsible for reviewing patient AVF access before each cannulation and responsible for complying with this policy.
5.3.2 AVG cannulation is performed only by trained nurse. The cannulation of a new mature access should be only performed by a skilled nurse in order to minimize the risk of trauma.
Practice Development Nurse
5.4.1 PDN is responsible to ensure all renal staff receives in-house individualised training on AVF/AVG & Buttonhole cannulation and update their clinical skills on yearly basis.
5.4.2 It is the practice development nurse responsibility to ensure that the policy and procedures are made available to all staff working within the renal unit.
CNS's (HD Vascular Access Specialist Nurses)
5.5.1 Vascular Access / Transplant nurse is responsible to monitor the AVF access for all pre dialysis patients every 2-3 months, depending on need, until they start haemodialysis.
5.5.2 HD vascular access specialist nurse is responsible for assessing arteriovenous fistula before cannulation.
Health Care Support Worker
5.6.1  The Health Care Support worker only attempt cannulation on patients allocated by a RN. The Health Care Support worker refers to RN if there is any problem regarding cannulation
Training
All medical staff and nursing staff are to ensure that their knowledge, competencies and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
All staff RN's and HCA's will receive in house training from the practice development nurse for rope ladder cannulation and are assessed on yearly basis by their team leaders.
Registered nurses undertaking buttonhole cannulation must have received specific training in the technique including observed practice and assessment of buttonhole competence.
All competency achievements are documented in the staff personal file. Annual review of staff competency should be aligned with annual staff appraisals.
The practical component of training involves observation of cannulation by a competent nurse.

All new RN/HCSW should cannulate AVF under supervision until the preceptor is confident that they are competent. They should have completed the Renal Cannulation Competency framework including practical and theory components.
Physical Examination for Maturing AV Fistula
In general, fistula should be assessed using Rule of 6's, a mature AVF should;
Be a minimum of 6 mm in diameter with discernible margins when a Tourniquet is in place
Be less than 6 mm deep
Have blood flow greater than 600ml/min
Be evaluated for non-maturation 4–6 weeks after surgical creation if it does not meet the above criteria
Sutures to be removed 7-10 days post AV Fistula Formation.
Allow the arteriovenous fistula to mature for 2-3 months after formation and before cannulation.
Allow AVG 3-6 weeks after placement before cannulation, this will allow swelling to subside.

Ensure the patient information leaflet has been given to the patient. Educate the patient on exercises which will enhance maturation of arteriovenous fistula. These exercises will increase the rate of AVF maturation by increasing blood flow causing the vein to engorge and arterialise. Patient can start exercising the fistula arm after the site has healed and the pain is minimal usually in one-two weeks' time.
Ensure to follow appendix  For cannulating a new AVF.
Arteriovenous Fistula

AVF is a surgical creation of an anastomosis between an artery and a vein thus allowing arterial blood to flow through the vein. This causes venous engorgement and enlargement, allowing large bore needles to be inserted for haemodialysis. Potential chronic HD patients should be ideally referred to the nephrologist and/or surgeon for preparing vascular access when they reach stage 4 of their CKD.
Arteriovenous Graft

A synthetic graft implanted subcutaneously and interposed between an artery and a vein allowing needles to be inserted in order to remove and return blood during haemodialysis. It is an alternative form of access for patients with inadequate vessels for the creation and maturation of an arteriovenous fistula
Maturation

Fistula maturation is a process by which a fistula become suitable for cannulation (i.e. develops adequate flow, wall thickness, and diameter). Fistula maturation should be monitored to allow pre-emprtive maturation if needed (EBPG, 2007).
Assessing the patients access
7.5.1 The arteriovenous fistula (AVF) remains the gold standard access for haemodialysis showing better survival and lower complication rates than grafts and catheter.
An AVF should be
Patent
Palpable with bruit present
Clean and free from signs of infection
Able to deliver adequate haemodialysis

7.5.2 Once a fistula has been formed it usually takes six weeks to mature. The patient should then be assessed for rope ladder needling technique i.e. a uniform use of the vessel, each needle is inserted about 1cm above the last site along the entire vessel or buttonhole technique.
Observation
Redness/Oedema/bruising
Infection/abscess/drainage
Previous needle sites
Infiltration
Choose new needle sites (Rope ladder technique)
Palpation
Track of the access
Thrill
Pulse
Auscultation
Listen to entire access with stethoscope every treatment, until the cannulation regime is established. Note changes in sound characteristics
A well-functioning fistula should have a continuous, machinery-like bruit on auscultation.
An obstructed (stenotic) fistula may have a discontinuous and pulse like bruit rather than a continuous one—and also may be louder and high- pitched or “whistling”
Hazards of cannulating fistulas
Infection
Haemorrhage
Risk of air embolism
Arteriovenous fistula damage
Needle stick injury
Risk of aneurysm formation
Contamination from blood leakage
Venous needle dislodgement during haemodialysis
Equipment
Protective gown and face shield or goggles
Clean dressing trolley
Dressing pack
2x 10ml NaCl 0.9% ampule or 10ml pre-filled saline syringes
17g, 16g, 15g or 14g haemodialysis needles
(fistula cath) Cannula x 2 as per the patient's care plan
Lignocaine spray or Emla cream (for sensitive patients).
Non sterile gloves for RLT cannulation and sterile gloves for BCT
1x Tape. 2 x Sterile plasters
2% Chlorhexidine swabs x 2 or Betadine if the patient is allergic to Chlorhexidine as indicated on the care plan
Packet of gauze
Blood sample bottles and connectors for routine/monthly bloods
Preparation
Clean hands as per MEHT Hand wash policy (04072 Hand Hygiene)
Clean trolley/ table with disinfecting wipes (Clinell universal wipes)
Identify your patient to acknowledge you have the correct patient
Ensure informed consent is obtained (Appendix 1)
Put on protective gown and face shield or goggles
Gather equipment
Prepare equipment on a sterile field: attach required tape to side of trolley
Place sterile drape underneath cannulation limb

Record and document patients weight, BP, pulse, temperature and respiratory rate. Advise patient to wash their fistula/graft site with soap prior to cannulation to minimise bacteria on the skin before inserting needles
Check the patency of the patient's fistula or graft by listening for a bruit and palpating for a thrill and report to charge nurse or medical staff if bruit/thrill is absent
Assess patient's access for signs of infection and report to charge nurse
Establish the direction of blood flow and appropriate cannulation sites
Ensure the patent's arm is well supported on either a pillow or the bed/chair and place protective sheet under patient's arm or leg
Apply tourniquet loosely to the arm if required (AVF only)
Perform hand wash, when hands are dry put on non-sterile gloves
Procedure (Refer to appendix 5)

Select cannulation puncture site. Promote rope ladder technique to establish maximal use of blood vessel for both arterial and venous sites. Discuss proposed cannulation site with patient and obtain educated consent.

Maintaining an aseptic non-touch technique, clean cannulation area with 2% Chlorhexidine swabs (one swab per site for buttonhole cannulation) or with Betadine if patient has a known sensitivity to Chlorhexidine. Allow the antiseptic to dry.
Prime fistula needle with 10ml NaCl 10ml syringe (do not needle with dry needle).

Tighten tourniquet on the patient's arm – the patient can do this if able (Rationale: To engorge the vessel and to assist with stabilization of the vessel to be cannulated.) Do not use tourniquet for AVG (Rational: The AVG is a firm structure).

Maintaining an aseptic non-touch technique, Patients with topical anaesthetics such as Emla patches should be educated to apply Emla cream30-60mins before starting dialysis. Give the patient an option to have no local (Emla patches must not be applied to button hole cannulation tracts).

Examine cannula and check it has a functioning clamp, the cap is on and there are no manufacturing faults. Leave the clamp on the cannula open and hold the cannula bevel side up and remove the needle cap

Use the non-cannulating hand to render the fistula still and assess the direction and depth of the vein at the same time. An effective way to do this is to stretch the skin on both sides of the vein with the thumb and index finger while pressing on the vein with the middle finger or use your thumb and index finger of your non cannulating hand on either side of the vessel, to help stabilise the vessel and prevent movement

Maintaining an aseptic non-touch technique and using a 30-35 degree angle for fistulas and a  degree angle for deep grafts, insert the cannula carefully. A flashback of blood should be visible once the needle is in the access. Once the bevel of the cannula is inserted, level out the cannula to an appropriate angle and advance slowly up to the needle hub.

Secure the fistula needle/cannula to the patient's skin by taping the wings. Use caution when taping needles as an improper needle flip or taping can cause infiltration. Apply sterile plaster over to the needle entry point to prevent systemic infection. Use EDTNA guidelines for securing needles (Refer to EDTNA Venous Needle Dislodgement Prevention Patient Information Leaflet).
Loosen the patient's tourniquet (the patient can do this if able)

Attach 5ml n/saline syringe to AVF needle and insert needle bevel up at 20-35 degree angle, loosen or remove cannula cap or remove syringe to allow the blood to flow back to the end of the needle/cannula tube. Take blood if required, then flush with 5ml of saline while observing for pain or swelling around the cannula area
Reposition or rotate the needle/ cannula if required or flow is sluggish
Cover the puncture site with a sterile plaster and secure needles with tape to prevent needle dislodgment.
Repeat procedure for the second needle/cannula (flush needle with n/saline before insertion)
Commence dialysis by connecting needles to primed dialysis circuit.
Remove gloves and perform hand hygiene
Discard sharps and waste appropriately (Sharps bin/ clinical waste bag)
Clean trolley and perform hand hygiene
Post Procedure Care
Needle removal/ arteriovenous fistula/ graft)
Clean and gel hands before starting to wash back..
Take needles out at same angle as needled in.
Use correct and firm pressure to the needle exit site.
Apply sterile dressing on each exit site.
Leave dressing for 5-6 hours post dialysis.
Patients taking oral anticoagulants or patients with high venous pressure due to venous circulation complications should have nd needle removed only when 1st needle site has achieved haemostasis.
Needle removal/ buttonhole cannulation
Clean and gel hands before starting to wash back.
Use sterile dressing pack post dialysis.
Take needles out at same angle as needled in.
Use correct and firm pressure to the needle exit site.
When bleeding stops clean exit site with betadine or Clinell 2% chlorohexidine skin wipe swab and apply Muprocin 2% (Bactroban) cream.
Apply sterile dressing on each exit site.
Leave dressing for 5-6 hours post dialysis.
Trouble Shooting

Managing infiltration: Explain to patient that infiltration and haematoma could occur most likely during the first two weeks of using the access. Educate patient regarding limiting arm movement while on haemodialysis.
Infiltration of a new AVF

If the fistula infiltrates let it rest for 1 week then go back to smaller gauge needles. If resting is not possible, the next cannulation should be above the site of infiltration. Notify CNM /Nephrologist
If it infiltrates a second time rest for 2 weeks and then reduce needle size. To prevent further damage to fistula, and allow healing. Notify renal consultant/renal registrar
If infiltration occurs a third time, notify access nurse, renal consultant. Consecutive infiltration could signify a problem with the fistula which requires radiological or surgical intervention.
Infiltration of the mature AVF:
If infiltration occurs before dialysis remove the needle
If Infiltration occurs after heparinisation, remove needle and once bleeding stops place another needle above the infiltrate site
Place ice on the site while patient is on haemodialysis
Apply dressing post dialysis
Infiltration of the AVG
Remove the needle immediately.
Apply ice.
Contact the nephrology team.
Administer analgesia as prescribed.
Refer patient to vascular access nurse sent urgently.
Establish the track
Same cannulator for approx. 8 cannulations for non-diabetic patients and 12 sessions for diabetic patients. (during this period sharp needles are used)
Always cannulate using the exact same spot, same angle and depth for each cannulation.
When the track is established, change to blunt needles – then other staff can cannulate.
Scab removal: Ensure scabs are removed prior to cannulation
Buttonhole track screening: (BCT track screening should be done every 3monthly)

Disinfect/clean arteriovenous fistula arm with 2% Chlorhexidine swabs, leave the skin to dry for 30-60 seconds, remove arterial scab, obtained swab, clean the track site with Chlorhexidine Sep and insert needles when the site is dry.
Repeat the same process for the venous site.
Troubleshooting of buttonhole cannulation.
If the sites you have chosen are not working, abandon the site and chose a new site.

If you have to use a different site (other than buttonhole) stay at least ¾” away from the buttonhole site to prevent damage to the buttonhole track ( If the patient is hospitalized in a different hospital)
Bleeding around the needles during dialysis could be caused by stretching the track or by cutting the track with sharp needles during cannulation.
If have difficulties getting needle in the right tract inform senior staff to
help.
Life threatening bleed
12.8.1 Prevention of LTB from AVFs / AVGs is of the utmost importance. Avoid area puncture cannulation of AVFs / AVGs.
12.8.2 Be aware of warning signs of an increased risk of a LTB from an AVF / AVG:

table_items.text: Any non-healing scab / wound over the AVF / AVG
Prolonged bleeding post haemodialysis or bleeding in between dialysis sessions
Aneurysms that are increasing in size, either at cannulation sites or elsewhere
Shiny, thin skin over the AVF / AVG, particularly over aneurysms
Other skin integrity issues in the

data.text: 12.8.3 The priority is to stop the bleeding, not preserve AVF or AVG function.
Once help from the emergency services has been initiated, patients should continue to apply direct pressure to the bleed.

All patients experiencing a spontaneous bleed from their AVF/AVG or felt at immediate risk of a bleed should be seen urgently by a surgeon who specialises in vascular access before they leave hospital.
If easily available, a small, rigid object (e.g. large bottle top, hollow side down) can be used to apply pressure over the bleeding site. This ensures pressure is localised to the area of the bleed.
Patients should be advised not to use a large absorbent item, such as a towel, as this disperses pressure reducing its effectiveness.
Do not advise patient to use tourniquets to manage LTB.
Incidents
Life Threatening Bleeding
Patients, carers, transport staff and emergency care staff should be educated to contact ‘999' in the event of a LTB from an AVF / AVG.
Staff will report about Life threatening bleed from fistula needle site within the unit or in an ambulance via DATIX.
Other Incidents
Any incident that results in patient harm must be reported on Datix
Audit and Monitoring

An annual audit of outcomes of life threatening bleed will be included in the ‘Access nurse Specialist' annual report. The finding of the audit will be reported in renal MDT and renal governance meeting.
Patient satisfaction survey results and response to negative feedback

Review of any complaints about the service with associated action plan for improvements and review of DATIX incidents / near misses with action taken to prevent recurrence. This data will be reviewed in clinical governance and this can help renal unit to identify trends in occurrence, aiding detection of potential LTB of AVF / AVG earlier.
Key finding and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.

Appendix: 2. AVF Infiltrations
What is an infiltration?
An infiltration (blow) means that the needle has been dislodged from inside the vein (fistula) or graft during needle insertion or during a dialysis treatment.
What can happen when an infiltration occurs?
When you have an infiltration, blood leaks outside of the fistula or graft into the surrounding tissues. This causes swelling and pain in the area.
Your fistula or graft will continue to function. It may become bruised, swollen and the
area may feel firm to touch.
How is an infiltration treated?
The needle is removed and pressure applied to stop the bleeding. Icepack will be applied while in the dialysis unit.
Advise patient to apply icepack or frozen pea packs to the affected area for 30 minutes only at a time. Wait ½ hour to apply icepack again.
Do this 6 to 8 times for the next 24 hours to reduce pain and swelling.
Give Hirudoid cream to patient for topical application three times a day.
Before applying cream advice patient to wash fistula arm with Luke warm water (it helps cream to penetrate into the skin and increase healing process).
When the vein is infiltrated, and it is not increasing in size or severity, re cannulate above affected site and document it on e-med notes under HD access.
Assess fistula each session after infiltration and document it on e-med under HD access notes.
If unable to needle arteriovenous fistula at all then take bloods, notify the renal consultant.
